MgAl2O4 spinel particles prepared by metal–chitosan complexation route and used as catalyst support for direct decomposition of methane Giselle B. Nuernberg a Edson L. Foletto b ⁎ Luiz F.D. Probst a Neftalí L.V. Carreño c Marcelo A. Moreira d a Department of Chemistry, Federal University of Santa Catarina, 88040-900 Florianópolis, Brazil b Department of Chemical Engineering, Federal University of Santa Maria, 97150-900 Santa Maria, Brazil c Technology Development Center, Federal University of Pelotas, 96010-900 Pelotas, Brazil d Department of Soil and Natural Resources, State University of Santa Catarina, 88520-000 Lages, Brazil ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +55 55 3220 8448; fax: +55 55 3220 8030. Graphical abstract Highlights ► MgAl2O4 spinel prepared by metal–chitosan complexation route was used as catalyst support. ► The Ni/MgAl2O4 was evaluated as a catalyst in the methane decomposition reaction. ► In the methane decomposition, carbon byproduct was mainly deposited as multi-walled nanotubes. Magnesium aluminate particles were prepared from biopolymer (chitosan) and Al–Mg solutions by the metal–chitosan complexation method. The MgAl2O4 spinel obtained was used to prepare a Ni catalyst support. The Ni/MgAl2O4 (20% Ni, w/w) was evaluated as a catalyst in the methane decomposition reaction. The influence of the reaction temperature and the catalyst reduction temperature and time on the methane decomposition, as well as on the properties of the carbon produced, was investigated. The materials were characterized using XRD, SEM, TEM, TPR, TGA and Raman spectroscopy analyses. It was observed that the catalytic behavior was dependent on the reaction operating conditions employed. Under the operating conditions used in this study the carbon byproduct is mainly deposited as multi-walled nanotubes (MWNTs). Keywords Methane decomposition MgAl2O4 Metal–chitosan complexation Carbon nanotubes MWNTs 1 Introduction Methane decomposition (CH4 →C+2H2) has attracted attention in recent years because it produces pure CO and CO2-free hydrogen [1–5]. In addition, this reaction process also results in the generation of very important carbon materials as byproducts (carbon nanotubes and nanofibers), which have gained considerable attention due to their excellent properties and potential applications [6–9]. The structure of the nanocarbon formed may be affected by a series of parameters including the type of catalytic support [10], concentration of methane in the feed [11], reaction temperature of methane decomposition [12], amount of catalyst [13], textural properties and size of the catalyst particles [14], metal catalyst reduction temperature and time [15], catalyst calcination temperature [16] and methane flow rate [17]. Among the various direct decomposition catalysts, it is well known that Ni is one of the most effective [18,19]. This metal has been supported over different materials (Al2O3, TiO2, ZrO2, MgO, SiO2, MgO·SiO2, H+-ZSM-5, USY, MCM-22, MCM-41, NiCuAl, LaNiO3) and the effect of these supports on the methane decomposition reaction has been examined [20–26]. Herein, we report a simple and versatile procedure for the synthesis of metal oxide particles (MgAl2O4) with high surface area and large pore volume containing mainly mesopores. The method consists of obtaining a hybrid compound of aluminum–magnesium hydroxides and the biopolymer chitosan. Through the polymer elimination by thermal treatment a porous MgAl2O4 particle is obtained. This material has received a great deal of attention as a technologically important material on account of its attractive properties such as high melting point (2135°C), high resistance to chemical attack, good mechanical strength from room temperature to high temperatures, low dielectric constant, excellent optical properties, and low thermal expansion [27–29]. Due to its resistance to sintering, magnesium aluminate spinel has been used recently as a catalyst support for the steam reforming of methane [30–32]. However, a review of the results reported in the literature shows that the use of this material as a metal support for the direct decomposition of methane is scarce. We have recently shown that magnesium aluminate spinel (MgAl2O4) could be used as a metal support for this specific reaction promoting decomposition of CH4 in low temperatures for this reaction, as well as support Al2O3, SiO2 and MgO, fairly studied in literature, and the formation of carbon nanotubes with high degree of graphitization deposited on the surface of this material after the tests [11,15]. In this context, the spinel has been synthesized through the hydrolysis of metallic alkoxides of Mg2+ and Al3+ with further calcination. Our studies have revealed that the reduction temperature for the metal/catalysts as well as the concentration of methane in the feed have significant effects on the methane decomposition and quality of the CNTs obtained. The focus of this study was firstly to obtain MgAl2O4 via the metal–chitosan complexation method and subsequently to produce the Ni–MgAl2O4 catalyst by wet impregnation with an aqueous solution of nickel salt. The behavior of catalyst was evaluated under different conditions of reaction temperature and reduction temperature and time, in the direct decomposition of methane. Similar work was done by our research group in an article published recently [11], using the same catalyst, but prepared by sol–gel method. The characterization of the deposited carbon after the catalytic tests was carried out and the results are reported herein. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of MgAl2O4 support The synthesis procedure used in this study was similar to that developed previously by Nuernberg et al. [33]. For the synthesis of the support by the metal–chitosan complexation route, 5g of chitosan polymer [(C6H11O4N) n ] (Purifarma) were dissolved in 167mL of acetic acid solution (5, v/v), 5.21g of Mg(NO)3·6H2O were dissolved in 6mL distilled water and 21.35g of Al(NO3)3·9H2O were dissolved in 50mL distilled water. The Mg and Al aqueous solutions were then added to the polymer solution with magnetic stirring. The chitosan monomer to Mg and Al molar ratio was 1.5:1.0:1.4. The Mg–Al–chitosan solution was added dropwise with a peristaltic pump to a NH4OH solution (50%, v/v) under vigorous stirring. After adding the solutions, the system was kept under stirring for 3h to complete the gelification process. The gel spheres were separated from the solution and further dried at ambient temperature for 48h. This material was calcined in an oxidizing atmosphere (air) at 700°C, for 4h, to form the spinel phase. This material was employed as a support in the preparation of the nickel catalyst. 2.2 Preparation of the catalyst To obtain the Ni catalyst supported on MgAl2O4, nickel was impregnated through wet impregnations with aqueous solutions of nickel nitrate hexahydrate, where the nominal content of nickel in the catalyst was kept at 20% (by weight). The impregnation was carried out at 80°C. The samples were then dried in a drying oven for 16h, followed by calcination at 700°C for 5h in air. 2.3 Catalytic tests The CH4 decomposition reaction was carried out in a quartz-tube fixed-bed flow reactor (9mm i.d.) heated by an electric furnace. Prior to the reactions, the catalysts (100mg) were reduced in situ in a H2 stream at 550°C or 700°C for 1h or 2h, with a heating rate of 10°Cmin−1. The experiments were conducted under atmospheric pressure at 550 and 700°C. The reaction gas was composed of N2 and CH4 at a molar ratio of 7:1 (N2:CH4) [11]. The total flow rate of the reaction gas was 80mLmin−1. The reactant and the product gases were analyzed with a Shimadzu GC-8A gas chromatograph, equipped with a thermal conductivity detector, a Porapak-Q column and a 5A molecular sieve column with Ar as the carrier gas. In this study, the catalytic activity was evaluated in terms of methane conversion. 2.4 Characterization Samples were characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD) on a Siemens D-5000 (Karlsruhe, Germany) instrument, using Cu Kα radiation and monochromated graphite. The N2 adsorption–desorption isotherm measurements were carried out at 77K using an Autosorb 1C (Quantachrome) apparatus. Specific surface area and pore volume were determined at the equilibrium points P/P 0 in the ranges of 0.05–0.35 and 0.1–0.99, respectively, by the BET method. Temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) analysis was performed to determine the reducible species present at the surface of the catalyst and the temperature at which these species are reduced by H2. TPR was carried out with a Micromeritics Chemisorb 2705 analyzer, using 50mg of catalyst and a temperature ramp from 25 to 1000°C at 10°Cmin−1. A 30mLmin−1 flow of 5% H2/N2 was used. The thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out in a Shimadzu TGA-50 analyzer under an air flow of 50mLmin−1 with heating from room temperature to approximately 900°C at a heating rate of 10°Cmin−1. The morphology of the carbon-containing materials was examined by Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM) using a Philips XL30 scanning microscope operating at an accelerating voltage of 20kV. Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM), with a JEM-1011 microscope operating at an accelerating voltage of 120kV and Raman spectroscopy obtained on a Raman spectrometer (Renishaw – RGH22) with an Ar laser at a wavelength of 514.5nm were also used for the characterization of the materials obtained in this study. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization Fig. 1 shows the X-ray diffractograms of the support (obtained at 700°C) as well as the sample containing nickel after calcination at 700°C. According to the XRD patterns, all of the diffraction peaks can be perfectly indexed to cubic spinel-structured MgAl2O4 (JCPDS Card No. 77-1203). The XRD pattern for the Ni/MgAl2O4 catalyst also verified that the NiO crystalline phase interacted with MgAl2O4. The average size of the MgAl2O4 crystallite was determined through the Scherrer equation [34]: D = K·λ/(h 1/2·cos θ), where D is the average crystallite size, K the Scherrer constant (0.9), λ the wavelength of incident X-rays (0.15405nm), h 1/2 the peak width at half height and θ corresponds to the peak position (in this work, 2θ =36.89°). O crystallite size of the support before and after impregnation with nickel was 7.20 and 18.30nm, respectively. The increase of the crystallite size of support after impregnation with nickel occurs probably due to calcination of the Ni/MgAl2O4 catalyst at 700°C for 5h, promoting agglomeration and sinterization on the support particles [35,36]. The crystallite size of the nickel oxide also was determined from Scherrer equation (in 2θ =43.29°), with value of 4.30nm. The surface area and total pore volume of the support were 168.3m2 g−1 and 0.311cm3 g−1, respectively. Fig. 2a shows the TPR curve for the Ni/MgAl2O4 catalyst. Three peaks can be observed at around 450, 700 and 900°C. The first peak can be attributed to NiO reduction weakly interacted with MgAl2O4, the second peak to the reduction of Ni strongly interacted with MgAl2O4 spinel, and the third peak to the reduction of spinel (Ni,Mg)Al2O4 [37,38]. The nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms and pore size distribution for the catalyst are shown in Fig. 2b. According to the IUPAC classification, the isotherms in Fig. 2b are of type V, representing predominantly mesoporous structure characteristics (20Å< d <500Å). In addition, a small volume of macropores extends above 500Å. The porous structure was confirmed by analysis of the pore size distribution (see insert in Fig. 2b), which shows the spectrum for the pore diameter with defined maxima in the mesoporous region. The pore size distribution curve displays a wide unimodal distribution with an average pore size of around 177Å. It was found that the BET surface area and total pore volume were 28.2m2 g−1 and 0.125cm3 g−1, respectively. It was observed that the surface area and pore volume decreased drastically after nickel introduction, probably due to the second calcination of the catalyst and the amount of Ni (20% by weight) added to support causing blockage of the support pores by NiO [39,40]. 3.2 Catalyst performance In order to evaluate the catalytic performance of the Ni/MgAl2O4 sample, the methane decomposition reaction was carried out. Fig. 3 shows the catalyst behavior at a reduction temperature of 700°C, with different reaction temperatures (550 and 700°C) and reduction times (1 and 2h). According to the results, it can be observed that under all the conditions tested a high initial catalytic decomposition occurs followed by a rapid and gradual decrease in catalytic activity. In all of the tests, a total loss of activity was observed, except when the catalyst was submitted to the reaction process at 550°C with thermal reduction for 1h. It should be noted that this condition might have favored the reduction of reducible species leaving the active phase more available for catalytic activity. Additionally, the time until the complete deactivation of the catalyst became longer, which may also be related to the growth of the carbon filaments (as CNTs) on the catalyst surface causing the separation of the metal from the support surface, leading to a greater exposure to active sites and promoting a slower blocking of the active surface [39,41]. This finding is in agreement with the results of the TGA, Raman and TEM analysis. Fig. 4 shows the catalyst behavior at a reaction temperature of 550°C, under different conditions of reduction temperature (550 and 700°C) and time (1 and 2h). It can be seen that when the catalyst was submitted to the reduction process at 700°C for 1h, it does not show a loss of catalytic activity. This condition provided higher methane conversion values and the catalyst was more stable when compared with all other conditions. This behavior is probably due to a more efficient reduction of the active sites and/or growth of the carbon filaments, as previously postulated [39,41]. For the other tests, it was noted that there was a total loss of catalytic activity before 180min of the reaction. This may be due to a partial reduction of the active sites of the catalyst (550°C/1h), as can be seen from the TPR results (Fig. 2a), where the reduced species of Ni reduced these working conditions, are weakly interacted with the support. For the catalyst under the condition of 700°C/2h, it is speculated that the higher catalytic activity observed at the beginning of the reaction, may have been promoted by the most efficient reduction of active sites, however, there was a rapid loss of catalytic activity caused by catalyst sintering in the reduction procedure, leading to the active phase being less accessible to the flow of reagent which passes through the reactor bed and thus the reagent molecules are not converted into carbon and hydrogen products. This would result in the catalyst having a shorter lifetime [42]. 3.3 Characterization of deposited carbons TGA is a very powerful technique for determining the quality of the synthesized CNTs which is related to differences in the oxidation stability and degree of graphitization. It appears that various types of carbon, such as amorphous carbon and CNTs, have different oxidation temperatures and can be distinguished using the TGA technique [43,44]. The results for mass loss determined from the thermogravimetric curves (not shown here) of the Ni/MgAl2O4 catalyst after the catalytic tests under the different operational conditions applied in this study are shown in Table 1 . The TGA analysis of the Ni/MgAl2O4 catalyst after the catalytic tests at 550 and 700°C showed a mass loss in the region of 583–640°C for all operational conditions tested in this study, as shown in Table 1. The mass loss of the sample within the temperature range of 500–650°C corresponds to the thermal oxidation of MWNTs, this variation depending on the content of metal catalyst (since it was not removed from the material before the TGA analysis and then could catalyze the process) and carbonaceous materials, as amorphous carbon, present in the nanotube [22,45]. It can also be noted that only for the conditions of a reaction temperature of 550°C and reduction at 700°C for 2h (entry 2) did mass loss occur below 500°C. Under these operational conditions there was a mass loss of 3wt.% at 406°C, which can be attributed to the burning of amorphous carbon [46,47]. This small weight loss indicates that the amount of amorphous carbon present is low. The SEM and TEM micrographs of the carbonaceous materials produced after the catalytic decomposition of methane are shown in Fig. 5 . The SEM image presented in Fig. 5a shows the catalyst surface covered with carbon agglomerates. The TEM micrographs (Figs. 5b and c) obtained after the methane decomposition revealed the presence of multi-walled carbon nanotubes with a filamentous structure, as reported by many researches [9,20,22,47,48]. For all of the operational conditions employed in this study, in general, the outer diameter of the nanotubes ranged from 20 to 35nm, while the inner diameters remained practically unchanged (around 5nm). For the carbon nanotubes formed under the operational conditions of reaction at 550°C and reduction at 700°C/2h (Fig. 5c), for example, the outer and inner diameters for the MWCNTs were estimated to be ca. 25 and 5nm, respectively. The images in Fig. 5b and c also show some black points which may be attributed to the nanoparticles of Ni and/or amorphous carbon, which were involved and deposited on the walls of the carbon nanotubes. Similar behavior has been observed by Hsieh et al. [49], Zhou et al. [50] and Guevara et al. [51], employing metal and bimetal catalysts of Pt, Pt–Ni(Fe,Co) and Ni–Ce, respectively, and by Gallego et al. [46] using LaNiO3-type perovskite as a catalyst. Fig. 6 shows the Raman spectra for the carbon deposited during methane decomposition under different experimental conditions over the Ni/MgAl2O4 catalyst. For all Raman spectra, two bands were observed at 1350cm−1 (D band) and 1580cm−1 (G band). The G band can be attributed to the in-plane C–C stretching vibrations of graphite layers and the D band to the structural disorder of graphite [10,52]. From the Raman spectra in Fig. 6, the ratio between the D and G bands was calculated (I D/I G), and this can express the graphitization of carbon nanotubes or degree of disorder in the structure, which is related to the quality of the carbon nanotubes [46]. The graphitization degree of carbon nanotubes is higher for smaller I D/I G values. The values for the relative intensity of the D band to the G band (I D/I G) in the Raman spectra for the carbon nanotubes obtained under different operational conditions are shown in Table 2 . The sample with the lowest I D/I G value (I D/I G =0.48) was that obtained at a reaction temperature of 700°C, indicating that the graphitic order of the carbon nanotubes is higher on applying higher reaction temperatures. Similar results have been observed by Takenaka et al. [10]. In general, all of the operational conditions used in this study led to I D/I G values below 1.15, indicating that the carbon nanotubes are quite well graphitized, corroborating the results obtained by Gallego et al. [46]. This is confirmed by the oxidation temperature observed in the TGA (shown in Table 1). As observed in the TEM images (Fig. 5), MWCNTs were formed in the decomposition of methane under the operational conditions applied. Thus, the improvement of the graphitic order revealed by the Raman spectra in Fig. 5 can be attributed to the formation of these MWCNTs. 4 Conclusions The MgAl2O4 spinel was successfully prepared via the metal–chitosan complexation route. The synthesized material showed the formation of a spinel phase with a good specific surface area and porosity due to the temperature conditions used. The Ni/MgAl2O4 catalyst was prepared from the MgAl2O4 spinel obtained and used as a catalyst in methane decomposition. It was observed that the catalytic performance, activity and stability are dependent on the operational conditions employed. According to the results, the best conditions for methane decomposition were a reduced temperature of 700°C for 1h and a reaction temperature of 550°C. The results showed that the growth of MWCNTs is favored using the Ni catalyst supported on MgAl2O4 obtained via the metal–chitosan complexation route. The MWCNTs had inner and outer diameters in nanometric scale. References [1] Y. Echegoyen I. Suelves M.J. Lazaro R. Moliner J.M. Palacios J. Power Sources 169 2007 150 157 [2] X. Xiang L. Zhang H.I. coredata.dc:description: Magnesium aluminate particles were prepared from biopolymer (chitosan) and Al–Mg solutions by the metal–chitosan complexation method. The MgAl2O4 spinel obtained was used to prepare a Ni catalyst support. The Ni/MgAl2O4 (20% Ni, w/w) was evaluated as a catalyst in the methane decomposition reaction. The influence of the reaction temperature and the catalyst reduction temperature and time on the methane decomposition, as well as on the properties of the carbon produced, was investigated. The materials were characterized using XRD, SEM, TEM, TPR, TGA and Raman spectroscopy analyses. It was observed that the catalytic behavior was dependent on the reaction operating conditions employed. Under the operating conditions used in this study the carbon byproduct is mainly deposited as multi-walled nanotubes (MWNTs).
coredata.dc:title: MgAl2O4 spinel particles prepared by metal–chitosan complexation route and used as catalyst support for direct decomposition of methane
